basics.name: Christian Holm Johansen
basics.role: PhD Student in Health Data Science
basics.summary: PhD student applying deep learning methods to integrate omics and health registry data for predictive modeling. Dedicated to creating robust, reproducible software solutions that can deliver translational impact and real-world healthcare advancements.

work.name: Department of Public Health & Novo Nordisk Foundation Center for Protein Research,  University of Copenhagen
work.summary: Conducting research on the integration and representation of large, longitudinal electronic health record datasets for deep learning applications. A key outcome has been the development of a cost-effective early detection tool for young-onset type 2 diabetes, leveraging both primary and secondary care data within a transformer-based neural network. Additional work focuses on pretraining large deep learning models on EHR data to improve generalizability and performance, particularly in settings with limited labeled data.

work.name: University of Exeter
work.summary: Generated genetic risk scores for type 1 and type 2 diabetes and integrated them into a deep learning model to stratify adult-onset diabetes cases at the time of diagnosis.

work.name: Novo Nordisk Foundation Center for Protein Research, University of Copenhagen
work.summary: Contributed to a project integrating high-dimensional multi-omics data from newly diagnosed type 1 diabetes patients to predict future C-peptide trajectories, enabling targeted clinical trial designs.

work.name: Technical University of Denmark
work.summary: Developed attention-based neural networks to predict protein–protein interactions between peptide–MHC complexes and T-cell receptors.

publications.name: Multi-omics analysis reveals drivers of loss of β-cell function after newly diagnosed autoimmune type 1 diabetes: An INNODIA multicenter study
A Deep Learning Approach Across Primary and Secondary Care for Early Detection of Young-Onset Type 2 Diabetes
